dt.t: a writer known for his use of {wi}allegory{/wi}

dt.t: The poem is an {wi}allegory{/wi} of love and jealousy.

quotes.t: He saw thousands of Buddhas lined up in trays in the tourist shops … some in lead, some in wood, some carved in stone and dressed in a little knitted caps and capes. He came to see in this ubiquitous phenomenon the Buddha's godlike propensity for self-division, the endless fractioning of himself into every perceivable aspect, an {qword}allegory{/qword} made by the people of Japan from the cellular process of life.

Luther dismissed this mystical reading of the creative act as mere "{qword}allegory{/qword}." But for Augustine the six days are not just a rhetorical trope. They are unlike the figurative language of the curse on the snake. To say that Christ is a shepherd is a metaphor; but to say that he is light is literal, since physical light is a "shadow" of the real light spoken of in Genesis.

The Scarlet Letter is his masterpiece, because of the simplicity of its {qword}allegory{/qword} and the grandeur of its colonial, Jacobean setting—and because of its shocking subject so nervously handled. Hester and Dimmesdale are sacred and profane love, subjects for Titian, yet conventionally clothed.
